description:
Wow. Once again I am amazed about how much better the Mexican is here compared to the East Coast.

The homemade tortillas came out piping hot (YES), and the pork stew dish were my two favorites - in addition to the rice and beans. Excellent service and lovely ambiance. I will miss this place.....all the way from NYC!
author: Shu Jin S.

description:
Came here a couple of days ago. The wait? No one was in the restaurant. Okay maybe i am exaggerating there was maybe two other small tables occupied. 
Ive been here a couple of times and there usually aren't many people, so u never have to worry about waiting. 

The food? At first the food was alright. But then the last couple of times i came here they got my order wrong. And unfortunately the food was also cold
And my wife had a hair in her food?! Oh NO BIG DEAL. 
 
There was another occasion when i was craving something and i called ahead to make sure they are open, and the lady that answered the phone said they were closed but yelp said they were going to be open for another hour i asked her about the mix up and her excuse was that the manager wanted to close early because they had no customers. ‍
So i drove up there and guess what they were open!
‼
The service well, they pick and choose who to be courteous to. 

Honestly i will never come back
author: Paola R.

description:
I went into today at 1PM. We have gone other times and the service is usually a hit or miss. We have always returned because the food has always been good until today. 

My food had a long hair. Really long and it was under my tortilla. My rice and beans were cold and so were my wife's. 

They changed it and brought us some hot beans. When they brought me my check I thought at least a 10% off for inconvenience on having to wait for my food to be redone. Nothing. Not even an I am sorry from the manager. Now I am feeling this pain on my side and so is my wife. 

I think the health departnent needs to be revisiting this place. Also, the flavors are good for the most part. They are overpriced.


So apparently it was not a hair but it was a piece from the tortilla basket. Interesting. This owner does not want anymore patronage because they feel my review was unfair? I have posted a picture of what the owner sent. Also, I never asked for a free meal or comp. you said your food cost is high? A lot of restaurants have high food cost and they provide excellent service or apologize. I will be contacting the health department with the text showing that you admit I had strange item in my food. This is so it does not happen again to anyone else.
author: Jasmine N.

description: If you can't enjoy this place as much as I, you might just be dead inside. Everything tasted on point and was super fresh and authentic. The flavors are awesome, the ambiance inviting, and I just know I'm going to be coming here a lot in the future. I had the Mole Verde de Puerco. Epic. It might be a while before I can come here and order anything else. I also got a side saddle of Papas con Chorizo and recommend you give it a whirl too. It came with a side of their verde salsa which rounded out and brightened up the flavors. Chilaquiles was solid but I prefer my eggs a bit runny vs. the scrambled I tried.
author: Darin E.

description:
4.25 stars 

Yum! El Buen Comer fits nicely in that in-between category of Mexican restaurants; far from a dingy taqueria & just as far from overpriced, upscale quasi-Mexican eateries. 

Their thick & hearty chips are the perfect vehicle for buttery guac. Complex flavors like lime, spice, onion, & garlic running throughout. Fantastic! Top 5!

Rolled chicken tacos were delicious & crunchy. Tomatoey chicken tinga sat atop a fluffy, homemade corn tortilla. My lunch partner also ordered tacos & when she recapped our meal to my bf, said, "You wouldn't like it, it's not greasy enough!" For me, that's a plus, but I know that's a deterrent for the Mexican food aficionados in my life who like an oily shimmer on their carnitas & carne asada.

I'd be here more often if I could only convince my favorites to take a break from their greasy go-tos!
author: Fancypants X.

description: Solid spot! The make their own tortillas. Saw it on eater38, was a bit out there but service was great, food all in all good and reasonable prices. Would definitely recommend if you are in the area.
author: Steven G.

description:
Nothing bad to say about this little joint. Super low key, out of the hustle and bustle of the heart of the mission and yet retains the genuine Mexican flavor that you would find in any other fancy place off of Valencia.

Chips and guac - how could you go wrong? I think the price was a little steep ($9) but they did give us more guac than we could handle (3 people)

Rajas de crema Sope - mild/underwhelming taste. I found myself mixing the guac and salsa with it to give it a little more umph, although I will say that the tortilla had a nice crunchy base.

Mixed squash - nothing special about this dish. Ended up being just some cubed variations of squash that were sauteed, and I ultimately mixed it together with my mole and guac.

Pollo con mole - I was recently in Mexico city and fell in love with mole. Buen Comer's mole was pretty on par with the flavors I experienced then. Extremely delicious flavor, and tender chicken which is easy to shred. Definitely the highlight of our meal!

I'm definitely glad I checked this place out. Their selection of menu items is unique, I just wish that some of the other dishes I tried had had a more lasting impression like the mole did. If you come here, your best bet may be going with something that is meat based!
author: Allie L.

description:
First coming here I try the flautas it was so fresh and delicious. Then I was craving couple days ago Mole . Oh Man! I must say the Mole is so tasty  that my friend got Mole verde I was surprised it had Pork ... that's not the case I love it !!!!! 
-Great food
-Best customer service
-Organized
-Clean
author: Jennifer B.

description: I stumbled upon this place while visiting San Fran for business and wanted to meet a friend. Great flavors in the mole! Chill vibe. Good margaritas.
author: Kris B.

description:
Good quality Mexican brunch, no wait, just a 10 minute bike ride from the heart of the mission. I'd come back! 

THE COST: $53 for brunch for two (including tax/tip). Affordable, and filling!

SOPES
* Sope de Carnitas, Chorizo, & Chicharron ($5 each) - 4 stars
All were great! Tasty but small. 

PLATOS FUERTES
* Chilaquiles Rojos o Verdes ($13) - 3.5 stars
Good! Don't go out of your way for this, but if you're here and generally enjoy chilaquiles, this is a solid option.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
We came for Sunday brunch. This is our second time here. 
We ordered a sope tinga, which was very tasty and well seasoned. The mimosa was perfectly balanced. 
Rice and beans here are REALLY good. 
The milanesa carne asada came crisp but slightly oily.
The chilaquiles sauce is original, just like the Mexico city one. 
Definitely coming back for more original Mexico City food.
author: Marcia d.

description: Great authentic flavorful dishes and delicious Micheladas. I think one of the best spots in Outer Mission. Great service and attentive staff! All of the above will bring me back to this place.
author: Lola M.

description: My friend ordered takeout form this place and I was expecting your average Mexican to go food. No, I was blown away. This is quality homemade tasting food. The shrimp dish was so flavorful and the chips were the good kind - you know what I mean! I can't wait to try more dishes and come back for brunch.
author: Mark S.

description:
Not texmex or calimex food. This is Mexico City regional food. It's hard to find.

Get the pork and green mole. Thank me later. My friend recommends the Chile Relleno.

We are truly enjoying the plantains for dessert.

Service was outstanding.
author: Peter K.

description: Came here for lunch on a Sunday a few weeks ago and was amazed at the food and loved the atmosphere as well. We didn't wait too long for a table even though the place was packed. I ordered the carne asado and a green tortilla soup which might have been the special. I also ordered a plate of fried plantains for desert. Service was awesome as well. Everything I ate was scrumptious and delicious and will definitely go back again.
author: Hazel Q.

description: We always come to El Buen to satisfy our craving. I am from Mexico, and the food here is as authentic as it comes. From the sopes, to the chilaquiles, everything on the menu is amazing. The service is great as well. We always look forward to coming back!
author: Dahena L.

description:
Love this place! Service and food AMAZING!
Street parking, kind staff, family friendly, food to die for. You won't be disappointed
author: Lauraine E.

description: Came for Saturday brunch. The sopes were so good (the tinga I liked more than the carnitas), as were the chips and guac, but the margarita pitcher was overpriced at $35 for the quality.
author: Alice Z.

description: Hands down one of our favorite neighborhood eateries. The pork mole, tortillas, rice and beans are our go tos. So delicious! Happy to support this place. The people who work here are also very kind.  We are never disappointed.
author: Allison N.

description: Years of getting breakfast from their stand in the Noe Valley Farmers Market, finally this brick and mortar opened. And then finally I went for breakfast. I mean really it was out of this world. I'll call out the cactus salad: kinda a salsa looking thing that is just flat out amazing. Couple with friendly staff and just amazing fresh and spicy food...it's my new jam.
author: David S.

description: Friendly service, great food and beautiful story make up for a memorable experience. We ordered the chorizo taco, TWO rajas con crema tacos bc it was SO GOOD!.. such fresh & creamy corn and nicely paired with the poblano peppers! yum yum! You can definitely taste the corn tortillas with this dish. We also ordered the carnitas sope (very juicy and flavorful) and tinga sopa. As for the tostada.. we opted for their fresh cactus salad and that was truly refreshing. I also ordered a small cup of pazole on the side. That was good but a bit too limey for my tastebuds. I also got the Spanish coffee and it was just the right amount of cinnamon spice!My boyfriend ordered the chicken mole and he really enjoyed that as well. We'll be back hopefully soon!
author: Jenna L.

description: In a city that has tons of Cali-Mex spots, I've been looking for an authentic, homestyle Mexican restaurant and this is definitely it. The moles are amazing, as are the fresh tortillas. Make sure you leave room for dessert - the fried plantains are incredible. Wonderful service, too. I will definitely be coming back to this place.
author: Rachel L.

description: El Buen Comer is a gem for traditional mexican food in the city. The taco, sope and tostadas are incredible (especially the rajas con crema). The corn tortillas are so delicious that I caught myself eating them by themselves a couple times. The mole con pollo was rich and thick, with chocolate and tabacco notes. The michelada is the best I've ever had. Also, our waitress was super friendly and helpful.
author: Nicolas K.

description:
If you're ever having a sopa or tostada craving, El Buen Comer is your go to.  It's a bit fancier (and a little pricier) than your neighborhood tacqueria; however, El Buen Comer definitely can serve as a nice date night location.  

As a disclaimer, this is rather close to my house so we eat here all the time.  We usually get two to three sopas; for SF, a $10 to $15 meal is actually a pretty great deal.  We've tried almost all of the sopas- the chicarrones, the chicken tinga, rajas con crema, etc. They're all delicious in their own way. When I first tried the chicarrones, I loved them; the second time, not so much.  The real winner for me is actually the rajas con crema- it's my favorite and I actually crave it.

I was also on a healthier kick and ordered the cactus salad. It was ok, nothing spectacular, but I appreciate that they had a healthy option for me to get my daily helping of vegetables :)
author: Jenny C.

description:
This place was nothing special. The ambiance is kind of generic and cold, and the service was...fine. 

The food - decent but nothing to write home about. We had chips and guac to start, and it was ok - maybe a little too creamy. My sister and I both got the cheese enchiladas, and those, to me, were not great. They were topped - no, covered - with cottage cheese and cotija, which was a bit much and took away from the flavor of the dish, in my opinion. And the sauce didn't taste like the classic enchilada sauce. If I get a classic dish, I want the classic flavor!

Also - the Michelada was not great. The tomato juice was slightly sweet, which is not a welcome flavor in that drink, in my opinion. 

It is really hard to find great Mexican in this town!
author: Jessica C.

description:
This is more upscale and more expensive than a taqueria, but not quite as fancy or expensive as something like Nopalito, Padrecito in the city, so it kind of falls somewhere in between. The food here is definitely authentic and delicious, and the ambiance is nice enough for a date or a casual lunch/dinner with friends, without it feeling like you're eating in a hole-in-the-wall taqueria.

I got the sopes ($5 each), which is like a thick corn tortilla (handmade) and super delicious. You won't find sopes in a lot of other places, so if normally like corn tortillas, get these. I got one with chicken and one with carnitas and both were delicious - I have a hard time picking my favorite between the two. The meats were flavorful, not overly salty or saucy and the garnishes on top went with everything well.

It's not super cheap at each sope costing $5, but it's certainly nicer than eating at a taqueria and more authentic than some other nicer Mexican restaurants in SF. I would definitely come back to try more things.
author: Christina L.

description: Would give this place 6 stars if possible! Delicious food and excellent service. The salsa is delicious and can be used with every dish (especially the tamales)! Highly recommend the super veggie tacos, pork tamales, and huevos rancheros. There's outdoor seating so you can enjoy the Bernal Heights sunshine.
author: Sarah N.

description:
This is fast becoming my #1 place to take out of country European guests to learn how good Mexican food can be. 

We came on a Friday night. Normally I wouldn't go out on a Friday in the Mission but timing of the travels didn't give us a choice. ( Tip: though the place was booked full on Yelp we were able to call just a few days ahead of time and got a table, no problem. ) Peeps here are really nice. They said it wasn't normally busy at 8pm - the rush crowd would have left by then - but we made reservations anyways. We ended up getting drinks at Rock Bar and called to say we were running late and that wasn't an issue either. When we showed up it was just a 5min wait for them to prep a table for us. Glad we made reservations since the place was still full-ish.

By now we knew what we wanted so split a chicharrón sope followed by the mole verde (small), albondigas (small), calabacitas (small), tortillas (med), and arroz rojo (small). 

yum ... yum ... yum ....

total was $80 including tax & drinks for 3 people but not tip
author: Jean K.

description: Fresh, homey Mexican eats, including some harder-to-find dishes like nopales. The coffee is pleasantly cinnamon spiced, and the portions are not so huge. We had a reservation for weekend brunchtime here (via Yelp!), when it was busy but not too crazy. The inside of the restaurant is lovely and light-filled, and I'm happy to support a this place started by a female immigrant.
author: Jade W.

description:
A nice, quaint neighborhood restaurant, El Buen Comer is a great place to savor the flavors of authentic Mexican cooking. I came here in a group of three for brunch on a Sunday, and we were seated right away; by the time we left however, the restaurant was full of people. The service here was kind, and our server gave us a number of good recommendations.

We started our meal off with the chips and guacamole to share, and the guacamole was so fresh--the avocados used were perfectly ripe and very flavorful! We split a couple dishes for our main course--the plate of three sopes (extra thick tortillas) with chicharron, chicken tinga, and nopales (cactus) was good but not all that memorable. The Camarones a la Diabla was a hearty plate of very spicy grilled shrimp with onions, and the mole verde de puerco, or pulled pork in a green mole, was probably my favorite--the mole was made from and had a distinct flavor of pumpkin seeds, which were so nutty and toasty! The main dishes were served with rice and beans, and we also had a basket of handmade tortillas, which were deliciously thick and chewy!

Overall, this was a great place for a brunch in a friendly and homey atmosphere. The dishes were relatively expensive for what they were, and the seasoning could probably have been toned up for a few of the dishes; but nevertheless, this was some of the best Mexican homestyle cooking I've tried in the city!
author: David K.

description: Once and never again: Overpriced, boring food, below average service. Any whole in the wall place or street food corner will be more satisfying than this
author: Sarah N.

description:
Higher-end Mexican restaurants can be a bit too ambitious for their own good. I'm talking to you, CALA. On the other hand, some nail it pretty well on a good night. Fenix, that's you. This place is not quite at that level, but I do like its aspiration of producing a comida corrida dining experience more akin to what you'd have in a nice, little neighborhood in Mexico City. In other words, this is no counter-order taqueria. Chef/owner Isabella Caudillo is intent on producing her own specialty home cooking in a convivial setting that's bound to appeal to the hipsters and young families in the Outer Mission. The menu was small but appetizing.

I decided to try the $12 Enchilada Rojas, cheese enchiladas simmered in chile de arbol and tomato sauce accompanied by rice and beans (photo: http://bit.ly/2hFH23B). It was very simply made but definitely full of flavor with cojita cheese sprinkled on top and rice to help soak up the rich sauce. As a side dish, the $4.50 Jicama con Naranja was an unusually refreshing and spicy treat. Looking like French fries, the jicama was tossed liberally in chile, and then it was topped with a few orange supremes to brighten up the crunchiness (photo: http://bit.ly/2ikiYCr). I would definitely like to come back for the other Platos Fuertes like the Tacos Dorados or the Mole con Pollo. Everything looked good as it passed by.

FOOD - 4 stars...simple dishes that taste authentic and flavorful
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...nice setting, spacious and full of light for an easy Sunday brunch
SERVICE - 4 stars...enthusiastic but not too unctuous
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely a different take on Mexican dishes worthy of your attention
author: Ed U.

description:
Such great food and warm service!! The staff here is very friendly. They accommodated 14 of us at short notice. Great place for large groups.

The quantity was perfect for me but a little less for my husband. The mole was - THE BESTever! Chill casual ambience. The margarita was yummy potent!  Definitely would recommend it for a brunch.
author: Shreya B.

description: Delicious and amazing authentic Mexican food. One of the few places that truly puts the extra effort into flavor, portions, and authenticity. Still a hidden gem in a city obsessed with finding the next hip spot to fuel their foodie Instagram hype.
author: Kasia K.

description: Great service and good sangria with a casual ambiance. Food was ok, nothing special about it. Had a great time there catching up with friends.  Although staff was friendly and helpful in getting requests for people with dietary restrictions, I do not seek coming back here because of food, which was bland and not what I was expecting from other recommendations.
author: Lorely G.

description:
Had reservations for 6, which was great because I got to sample a whole lot of food!  It was busy, but not too noisy and the service was good.

Got 3 different kinds of sopas, (chicharron, chicken rojas and I forgot the other one).  I'm not a fan of chicharron, but I really liked this one, wasn't greasy like straight-up fried fat.  I like sopas to be doughier/thicker, theirs was kind of crisp & on the thin-side but I'd order these again, they put plenty of toppings on it.  Other Yelpers mention how they'd wish some dishes were spicier but there were sides of very spicy salsa for condiment.

I thought I didn't like the chicken mole because the mole had kind of a raisiny sweetness to it, but I found myself topping my rice, (3 times) and dipping tortillas, (2 times), into the sauce.

The hands-down star of the night was the shrimp diablo, so flavorful with  spices with a hint of sweet and the shrimps were very plump and fresh.

I had, (for myself), the thinly breaded steak and loved it.  I never thought thin slices of steak, kind of crisp being lightly breaded, fried and seasoned would be impressive but it had such a homey flavor, I was really glad I ordered it.

The menu changes slightly every night, so I was disappointed when they didn't have rice pudding, so I made up for it by ordering the lightly fried plantain slices with a side of condensed milk & flan.  The plantain slices were a but too starchy for me but I'm a sucker for condensed milk so I enjoyed it, (I couldn't finish it all, just about 60% of it).  The flan, though small, was very refreshing with a hint of rum and slices of strawberries around it.

I would come back again, although a bit pricier, the authentic and freshness and hand made factor makes it deserve the respect of slightly higher prices.
author: Johnnie N.

description:
Sooooooo amazing! I absolutely loved the family style (shareable) plates. The red mole was possibly the best I've had in my life and everything else was on point!

The service was great. Super warm and helpful. 

And the made-to-order tortillas were To. Die. For!!! Unless you like shoveling mole (and other delicious dishes... but definitely get the mole... and a large) into your mouth with some rice and beans, I'd suggest getting at least a large order of the tortillas. They go beautifully and put anything in them, and you instantly have a mouthwatering taco.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Especially delicious food! I had Chile Relleno and they were better than when I lived in Tijuana! You guys rock! The service was amazing, the tea that they give in the authentic clay made mug, and the warmth of feeling like I'm in my favorite breakfast spot in Playas de Tijuana. It was truly a great start to our day in San Fran and took me back to my favorite parts of Mexico. El Bueno Comida is true to its name! 
Estoy feliz sobre mi comida! Gracias!
author: Mahdiah A.

description:
I would love to give them 5 stars. 

Their food is exceptional but their service sucks. Servers need better training. Feels like we're always waiting around - yet- we will still go because of the food! Fresh tortillas, best mole in the city, chicken tinga. Yum! I wish the atmosphere was a little warmer and didn't feel so much like a cafeteria.
author: Lina M.

description:
Where is the negative Star choice?

THIS PLACE IS OVERPRICED! THE FOOD IS BLAND AND VERY MUCH NOT WORTH THE PRICE OF ADMISSION. I cannot be more truthful or clearer.

My wife was born and raised in San Francisco and I moved here from Los Angeles two decades ago and we both know when we've been played on a meal. It happened last night at this place.
author: Steven M.

description: It's was great salsa was nice and hot like we love, omg homemade tortillas mmm and chips yes, game changer!!
author: Megan J.

description:
When I suggested coming here to a European friend, she said she didn't much like Mexican food. Now it's her favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  
Everything I've had here has been great (well, I've had better margaritas, but I come here to EAT). They also serve an amazing chicken pozole you may have to ask for. I remembered it but couldn't remember what it was called, and was disappointed when I couldn't find it on the menu. But then I just described it to the server, he smiled knowingly, and a mouth-watering, steaming bowl of it appeared. The service is very warm and accommodating - and if you're looking for gluten-free food, much of it is.
author: Sylvie L.

description:
The food is amazing with a great story. El Buen Comer started when the owner (Chef Isabel) sold her delicious food from her Tenderloin apartment and in the Noe Valley's farmers' market. Eventually, she was able to open up El Buen Comer -- her first restaurant! 

I came here with a group of 6 for lunch on a Saturday. We made reservations, but there was plenty of room for us even if we didn't. The ambiance was spacious and had a relaxing and cute atmosphere. The service was great -- our waitress was super friendly and accommodating. 

My friends and I decided to order different items on the menu and share. The food portions were smaller than expected, especially for the price. However, the quality of the food was incredibly tasty and made with care.

WE ORDERED:
- Chips and Guacamole: chips are from their homemade tortillas. The guacamole is avocado, cilantro, lime, with cubes of queso fresco on top. Very light and fresh tasting. 

- Mole Verde de Puerco: pork stew in a sauce made from pumpkin seeds, tomatillos, cilantro and epazote. One of my favorites! The pork was tender and the sauce was thick and creamy. 

- Chilaquiles Rojos o Verdes: crispy corn tortillas smothered in either homemade salsas and topped with egg or chicken. Another one of my favorites! It wasn't greasy or soggy. 

- Pollo en Morita: Braised chicken in a chile morita sauce. 

- Chicken Taquitos Dorados: another favorite! My friends and I were so full, but decided to still get these. We did not regret it. 

- Tinga Taco: pulled chicken simmered in tomato, onion & chipotle. Really delicious chicken and sauce. 

- Churros: comes with chocolate sauce for dipping. Not too sweet, but still a light dessert.

Although it's a bit pricey, you pay for the quality. I loved every bite. I would definitely come here again!
author: Kristal D.

description:
So, I finally get over my fear of dining solo for lunch and then this happens at El Buen Comer:

Dude *looks at empty chair*: "Are you waiting for someone?"
Me: "Nope."

Dude: "Awwwww, you're eating by yourself?"
Me: "Yes, I am."

Dude: "You shouldn't eat alone, let me buy you a drink."
Me: "Sure, I'll take a double Hendricks straight up with a twist."

Dude: "But, there's no full bar here..."
Me: "You're observant."

Dude: "........."
Me: "Have a nice day!"

Ok, I'm not that mean but I did think of responding sarcastically when he offered to buy me a drink (it was a really nice gesture but I just wanted alone time). If you see someone dining alone, please don't pity them. Many do it by choice. While I use to get major anxiety from it, I now relish the serenity, not to mention the solo foodgasms. 

El Buen Comer opened in early June and I've been eyeing this place because I read that the owner started a restaurant out of her living room in the TL. With the help of La Cocina, she started doing pop-ups at the Noe Valley Farmer's Market and now has her first brick and mortar in Bernal Heights.

El Buen Comer serves up authentic, Mexican food - none of that overpriced hipster Mexican food (e.g. Tacolicious, Mateo's, Padrecito, Velvet Cantina). Their specialties are guisados, slow-cooked stews. Don't have your heart set on anything you see on their online menu because the menu changes daily. I wish they could post on social media their menu for the day since a lot of people do choose restaurants based on the menu and their dietary restrictions. 

I initially came in for the Mondongo, tripe stew that I saw on their online menu but they didn't have that. The only guisado they had for the day was a pork mole. I wasn't feeling pork so I decided to order something I normally wouldn't: Milanesa de Res, a breaded beef filet ($14) which was served with rice, black beans, salad: http://bit.ly/29L0EM0 and housemade tortillas: http://bit.ly/29RmH4z. 

The milanesa was lightly breaded and had a jerky-like texture because it was pounded so thin (I think I ordered wrong). The rice and beans were simple and enjoyable, as were the freshly made, thick, hot corn tortillas. The salad was my favorite part of the dish. The greens were perfectly dressed in a creamy and tangy dressing, and I liked the tart crunch from the apples. Portions were fine for me but I don't think this would be filling for a hangry man. 

I had to sample more than one thing from the menu so I also ordered two Sopes: Chicharron and Tinga de Pollo ($3 each): http://bit.ly/2a6hqqG. Initially, I thought they were going to be super small like the ones at Cala but these sopes were sizeable (4 bites vs. 1 bite) and super delicious with the duo of salsas. Both were savory, flavorful, and had great texture. The chicharron was my fav as I love pork rinds. 

Service was super friendly, prompt, and attentive since I was one of three tables there at the time. 

Loved the contemporary rustic space - high ceilings, wooden furnishings, open kitchen, and teal tiling. Great for a casual date or for a large group dinner. 

Parking is easy during lunch on the weekdays and weekends but can be a nightmare at night. 

I hope the owner considers posting their daily menu on social media because I really want to try one of their guisados. The restaurant industry in the SF is super cut throat so I'm rooting for El Buen Comer to do well!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I have been 3 times now and each time I've ordered something different.  And each time I am blown away by the quality and taste of the meal.  The guacamole is from heaven and the salsa is so unique and authentic.  

The service is great as well!

Go here!  Now!
author: Maryn R.

description: First time here and it was delightful. Prompt service, delicious food, relaxing atmosphere. The mole was exquisite and like most dishes had a slight kick  I would recommend the mole, chilaquiles, and sopes. If you're looking for some authentic Mexican food, this place hits close to home.
author: Damaris S.

description:
We came here for lunch on a Saturday and had a nice meal.  Good food, good service, and elegant, upscale decor.

My husband got the 3 tacos combo: 1 chicarrones, 1 chicken tinga, and 1 chorizo & potatoes (the one he liked best).  I got the tacos dorado - a chicken taquito-like dish.  They were good, though I wasn't blown away.  We shared the small chips and guacamole, and found it very fresh and tasty.

Our waitress was quite friendly, helpful, and accommodating.  The food came out promptly.

The setting is new, elegant, colorful, spacious, and inviting.

It's a bit pricey for Mexican food, but you're paying for the upscale setting and that fresher taste, I suppose.

Good spot overall!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Saw this article in SFGATE: http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2016/06/09/another-la-cocina-success-story-el-buen-comer-opens-in-the-mission/

Came here for brunch on a Saturday - no wait we got right in.

We split the Chilaquiles (added Chicken and egg) and the Green mole pork.  (the menu has a bunch of stuff that stays and a bunch of rotating items).

They were both good - not huge portions. I really loved the chilaquiles, only complaint that one egg was overcooked so the yolk didn't spread. The small corn tortillas (2) that come with the pork entree were VER VERY good. we ordered 2 more (they charge $1.50 which is fine since they were hot and hand-made).

We ordered a churro for dessert. it came with a thick chocolate sauce for dipping.

The service was good...slow(isn) - not too slow - but don't come here for a quick meal.  I wish we ordered a sope for an appetizer.

Loved this place - will come back - but it is way our in Bernal Heights.
author: Amy W.

description: Cute restaurant in San Francisco. Cutesy Mexican dishes and decoration. Food was AMAZING! We ordered taquitos, shrimp and mole and all three were so delicious. I felt like I was in Mexico City. Their corn tortillas were authentic and thick and just perfect for the mole and the shrimp. Highly recommend.
author: Reyna S.

description:
Friendly service and delicious food.

The Guacamole and tortillas were fresh and flavorful.

The Mole was complex, delicious and loaded with tender chicken. 

The sopes were slightly crispy and piled with toppings.

The plantains were sweet and lovely.

Great authentic Mexican food served well, without pretense. Loved it!
author: Corey C.

description: Omg the food was so good here! We ordered margaritas, chips and guacamole, green posole with chicken, a carnitas tostada, and a papas con chorizo taco. Everything was delicious but especially the posole (perfect amount of heat and complex flavors). Prices were reasonable ($6 for the "cup" of posole, which was huge and really a "bowl"; $5 for a tostada or taco).
author: Heidi B.

description:
We had lunch and it was a good experience. I was happy that the portions were small, that way I was able to try a couple things. All of them were good. As chilango I like it, but it didn't impress me.
We'll be back when we are in the area
author: Luis S.

description: This is good home style cooking at exorbitant pricing. I've been here a few times and I am pleased with the food and shocked at the bill for what it is.
author: Mark P L.

description: The food is pretty good. However it's pretty overpriced and for the price, I'd expect at least big portions- they happen to be pretty small. The $16 mole was tasty but came with two small pieces or chicken. The tortillas that come with this are super good, clearly handmade corn tortillas and slightly thicker than normal. I normally skip tortillas but these were really fantastic in both taste and texture. The chorizo and potato sope was pretty good too, loved the salty chorizo with the potatoes. The sangria was just ok, nothing special and I would skip it in the future. Overall, the food tasted homemade and was tasty and the mole had a nice depth of flavor. Service was good too- were in a bit of a hurry and they made sure things came out quickly and got the check fast. My main thing is that you can get equally good, or better, Mexican food at a much better value in San Francisco and that's why I'm not sure I would come back here. I also didn't like the chicken in my chicken mole- the sauce was great but the chicken was a little over cooked and not too enjoyable. I actually preferred the sauce on its own with the rice and tortillas.
author: Seema U.

description: The food is great. Had a carnitas gordita and a milanesa de rez. I enjoyed both. My only complaint is the fake flowers on the table. Its so cheap and this world needs all the real plants it can get. And they were succulents. Fake cacti! Succulents are so easy to maintain there should be a law against fake ones. But I any case I'll back!!!
author: Keith R.

description: We had high hopes but this place was underwhelming.  Our brunch items were just boring and flat in terms of flavor, and the chilaquiles were especially off the mark.  Really disappointing.  Also pretty sure it was this brunch that made my wife's stomach pretty upset.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Pretty nice eatery in the San Francisco mission district. The salsa was actually spicy which I enjoyed, the guacamole was on point, a little small but enjoyable. 

The food was definitely authentic, from the silverware to the food itself. The enchiladas were really good, the flavor was on point. 

The Aguas Frescas were delicious, again a little small but very very yummy.

The reason I'm not giving a 5 star is the Camarones a la diabla isn't traditionally like a soup, I wasn't expecting it, and it was so watery that the shrimp didn't hold its flavor, I couldn't even use the tortillas they gave me because the sauce was water and ran right through the tortilla immediately. So I literally just ate shrimp and tortilla with nothing else on it, I was disappointed to say the least.

I do think that I would still go back and revisit this place. Overall the experience was good, the service and ambiance were also enjoyable.
author: Aram K.

description:
Overpriced. Lacked authenticity. No value for the amount of food you receive. They charge you for side salsa, beans, rice, and extra tortillas. 

Carne Asada was the best thing we ordered. Guacamole was simple and good with thin crispy tortilla chips. 

Left feeling unsatisfied, and wishing I went somewhere else in the mission.
author: Audrey G.

description:
Disclaimer: I have only ever had the sopes here. However, they are seriously the BOMB.

Don't be fooled by this more posh looking Mexican restaurant. I thought -- theres no way this can be authentic Mexican food. Well never judge a book by its cover! You cannot go wrong ordering the sopes here. Sopes are like a taco filling, but on a fried thick, corn based base. The slightly raised edges of the base help to hold in the copious and juicy filling. I've had the Tinga, Chorizo and Carne Asada all of which were perfection. I have also ordered the guacamole here, and though expensive, it comes with a very generous portion for sharing between a table. My mouth is watering just writing this review.
author: Amy T.

description: My work helped this place from a small establishment at La Cocina to being able to open their own restaurant now! They spoke at a few of our events and we are a big fan of theirs. We came here for an all-staff lunch and they had great customer service. The food was yummy and we had a good time. A great restaurant to support as the owners had a wonderful story. https://missionassetfund.org/food-family-isabels-story/
author: Jennifer T.

description: Excellent, wholesome, deeply flavored Mexican moles and stews. If you are always on the lookout for homemade tortillas and authentic Mexican home-style cooking, this place will transport you right to Mexico.
author: Laura B.

description: Horrible service at this place. Rude staff. Don't go. You will just end up with a bad experience. So many other great places around.
author: Jens S.

description:
In comparison with long-time Mexican brunches in the Mission, this was not even worth trying. Lured by the high reviews we were severely disappointed with sparse/cold atmosphere, long wait to order (20+ minutes), and longer wait to get our food (nearly 30 min.) When we asked, the server told us that there were to-go orders ahead of us. With such great hospitality at Mission restaurants, we've never had such a wait nor such an excuse.

The food was good, but not great. Chips and guacamole were very good and hand made corn tortillas were noble. But sauces were dumbed down and lacked the deep flavor Mexican food is known for. Except for the clear effort in making the tortilla, the quesadilla was unimpressive, with a wad of cheese inside. Refried beans were soupy and rice was served only in thimble size. Mole was mediocre in flavor. 

Good effort but poor results. I would not recommend this place nor go again.
author: T G D.

description: I'm afraid I got food poisoning the first and only time I ate here. Chilaquiles, salsa, and guacamole:(
author: Gabriela W.

description:
10.02.16

Two couples at brunch after attending separate weddings the night prior. Time was needed for stories to be exchanged. But more importantly, we needed strong and delicious coffee and greasy food to soak up the booze left in our systems.

El Buen Comer came up via the Eater SF brunch heat map. Score one for that page, as we would have never stumbled here without it. And I would not have had such delicious tostadas!

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-buen-comer-san-francisco-3?select=aNOdUNdHQvJj2CaeiGUJfA&userid=tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ

Fan.
author: Jenny L.

description:
One look at the menu, and you know this is not a typical "Americanized" Mexican restaurant.
Even if you see some familiar items such as tacos, you know this place is special when your order doesn't arrive in 30 seconds. There is no fully cooked food sitting in steam tables to slap on a tortilla and serve.
The menu has some creative dishes that you have not eaten before. We tried one that was all veggie, and it was so good I ordered it on our second visit.
I will take friends here, even friends from out of town
author: Wayne S.

description: Great place, superb service and tasty food - very clean and nice atmosphere with authentic food. Don't know why this place isn't busier because I can't even think of a negative thing to say.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I wanted to love it based on the Eater review and their "Mexico City" theme, given my recent trip there. We did like our kind waiter. And that there was no wait. And the food was fresh, and not greasy. However, the eats were not especially memorable.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Really great service, uplifting and colorful interior, and the Mexican food here is top notch.

I'd like to point out this is an actual Mexican restaurant not a taqueria. I love taquerias but there are so few restaurants in the city and I'm grateful to have this by my house. Thx.
author: Will D.

description:
I love how fresh this place feels, the sangria is a must try totally loved it, it was delicious some of the best sangria anywhere I think the other place where I had a lovely sangria was at RED-O on Melrose by Richard Bayless. The portions are small I like to eat so I would probably order 2 plates. 

Great coffee.
author: Victor L.

description:
I just don't know.  Have you ever eaten at a restaurant and left wondering "Am I happy?  Did I like that place?"  My experience here had pros and cons.  Honestly, when I got my plate I was taken aback by the 2 tablespoons of rice that came with my dish.  I had the $13 enchiladas verdes, which were very tasty...but the portion was definitely on the smaller side. I really wasn't sure if I had gotten enough to eat.  We also had to wait 20 minutes to order, which is a bit too long when you're taking a lunch break from work.
*** added a Star after receiving an email from the owner explaining that they are temporarily short staffed and that I can ask for more rice next time . I love an owner that cares!
author: Freedy H.

description: First time here was for lunch & it did not disappoint! Family environment with such good food & great customer service! Will definitely come back!!
author: Mayra R.

description:
Amazing food for any occasion. I loved the feel of the kitchen being exposed as you wait for your food. Almost felt like my childhood, when I would be in the living room watching tv as my mom made our food next door. 

Went to this place for Mothers Day and treated my mom and my family. We ordered the following items:
2 enchiladas verdes
1 camarón ala diabla
2 carne asadas 
1 pollo con mole

Enchiladas were so delicious, i don't know what they put in that green sauce but wow!

Camarones have a great flavor also

Carne asada plate felt like maybe the carne can be marinaded differently 

The mole was a different flavor and was delicious also.

I would definitely recommend coming for food here 
And if you're drinking the Sangria is great to start with.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I found this restaurant on SF Eater Brunch Heat Map for Dec 2016. I'd never heard of it beforehand, but reviews were excellent and so were the pics! Apparently this place had been a food truck in its former life, but now they have a brick and mortar. 

We came here on a Saturday at 11:45am. We waited maybe 10 mins for a table to open up. The ambiance is amazing - high ceilings with a rustic yet modern Mexican feel, and large windows that allow light to pour in from the street. What a beautiful venue! They also have a large communal table that has bar seating - seemed like a fun table to sit at!

All the pics on their Yelp page looked great - so my bf and I shared the 3 Sopes for $10 (which are kind of like tacos, but thicker, softer, made of corn, and lie flat). You can choose whatever meats you want, so we got the chicken tinga, red rice and egg, and chorizo. We loved the chorizo and tinga ones!!! The neat thing is that you can also get the taco or tostada version of these too. We loved trying the Sopes though since we don't usually see those offered at Mexican restaurants. 

Guacamole is a MUST. If you're like my bf and I, who basically want to try everything on the menu, they have the small or large option. The small was definitely large enough for our bellies to be satisfied, and for us to try it! It didn't have the cheese like it did in pics, but it still tasted a-mazing! I also got the pork Milanese for my entree which I loved! I love cutlets in general though. It came with beans, rice, and 2 tortillas. Loved it! Wish I saved the pics!

Service was extremely friendly and hospitable during our meal. They were attentive to refilling waters and also answering questions. Can't wait to return to try everything else on the menu!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
OMG. OUT OF THIS WORLD!! So...San Francisco is known for its amazing food. We know this. But what I'm NEVER able to find in the last 15 yrs is a good sit down Mexican restaurant. I'm talking authentic. So when I stumbled on this place, I just had to check it out!! Wow. This place is the closest thing to Mexican food from Mexico that I've ever had. Incredible. Don't go here looking for enchiladas and the usual. The menu is small but hand crafted and the food is amazing. 

I had the Tinga Sopes to start which are basically a marinated shredded chicken on top of a deep, crispy tortilla with beans and lettuce and cheese. SOOOO GOOD!!! It's been a day and I'm already craving more. 

Followed that up with the Camarones a la Diabla (shrimp guisado/stew) with a side of Rice and Beans. 

Again I can't say enough. Incredible service. Delicious food. And AUTHENTIC. I will be back!!!
author: Cynthia Q.

description:
Being Mexican i have a very high expectation for any Mexican restaurant and it's really hard to find a place where they serve real authentic food. In my case i was Born and Raised in Mexico City (DF) and grew up eating the best food you can imagine. 
El Buen Comer (family owned) has brought back all those fantastic memories of all the delicious food and antojitos (snacks) with the atmosphere of being home. 
I can say this is the ONLY restaurant that Serves authentic Mexican food in the city of San Francisco (Mission District)
author: Adrian G.

description: Just adding some info on how awesome this place is. The aguas frescas (fruit juices) are out of this world. They've tailored their menu and it is even more amazing. The 'rajas con crema' tastes just like the ones my mom makes. They also have ceviche now which is super fresh. The family atmosphere is so warm and cozy.  I feel right at home every time I eat here.
author: Michi R.

description: Was a little skeptical about this place due to the prices n some mixed reviews but great place love the poodle and the moles real authentic, some of the best service I had made me feel at home , I recommend not to go on sundays busy day
author: John A.

description: Still mediocre. Chips and guacamole and wine based cocktails good (only beer and wine). Food not good. Staff are very friendly and efficient but that's about it. I didn't see any Latinas/os in the entire place (except for me). I wish them well but I wouldn't recommend.
author: Rude G.

description: The best Mexican food we've had this side of Mexico City. This is one of our new favorite spots in the neighborhood.
author: Andrew M.

description:
HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE.
I have NEVER walked out of a restaurant because of the service, until today!!
I'd been here a couple of times in the past and the food was good, though a bit over-priced. 
I went with two other friends for brunch today,  and was seated at a corner table, (obviously meant for two people), thinking that they would bring over a third chair, so we could each have a side of the table rather than sitting in each other's laps....but they never brought the chair.
We asked our very nice waitress for a third chair, and she went to check with the hostess, who came back and said they needed ALL the other chairs in the restaurant for "reservations." Hmmm....we thought....that's rather poor customer service...putting us at a table without proper seating and then refusing to make us more comfortable, but we went ahead and ordered our food. The table next to ours was set for 6 people, (apparently, one of the "reservations" they were expecting), but after they were seated for a couple of minutes, one of the guests removed one of the 6 chairs to the side of the restaurant, because they were apparently only going to be a party of 5. I went to get the discarded chair and brought it to our table, because, we couldn't get any body to really pay attention to us. At that point the "manager" came over and said to us that they still needed that chair, now for another "reservation." We couldn't quite reason how if the party of 6 was now only a party of 5, how come they still needed the extra chair, at which point the manager became rude and hostile. At this point the table next to ours chimed in, in our support, which only infuriated him more. He said it was his restaurant, and he is entitled to refuse service to whoever he chooses...essentially threatening to throw us out. Well, he didn't need to as we chose to leave after being treated so unbelievably disrespectfully!
author: David M.

description:
This place had me smiling real big. 

Newly opened, designed to be modern, spacious, and welcoming. Staff is friendly. Great value.



FOOD:

1. Recommend the 3 for $10 sopes/tacos. Great deal and very authentic/delicious. 

2. The guacamole size "small" is huge, plenty for 2 or 3 people $6. 

3. Order their special $14 Milanesa de res - which is a breaded thin fried cutlet of beef. SO GOOD!!! ORDER THIS :)
author: Heidi C.

description: Had a good meal with a group of friends.  We basically had a sampling of many of the guisados and plates given a couple dietary limitations.  They're all a bit stodgy, so I would have loved some vegetables to go along with the meal.  Pricy but not outrageously so.  I'd argue that they're a three dollar sign place rather than the two dollar signs Yelp has listed.
author: Oliver D.

description: This place is so authentic! All ingredients taste organic. Well balance flavors. Portions are just right not to much or too little. Every single item in the menu haven't disappointed me. This place is awesome!!!
author: Nayely S.

description:
Living nearby, I have seen this building transform for the better part of a decade.  From an insurance and real estate office, and over the past few years, now this corner is El Buen Comer. 

The story is the owner/Chef Isabel began selling her delicious food from her home and in Farmer's Markets.  With the assistance of La Cucina,  she secured her own restaurant to serve her following.

I stopped in earlier today, in eager anticipation.  I began with some chips and 2 salsas.  The Chili de Arbol was spicy and my favorite over the tomatillo.   The latter was bright and acidic and very tasty.

I ordered the Albondigas. Three golf ball size meatballs, accented with a bit of mint.  It may not seem like much but I was pleasantly full after my meal.  The rice, beans and home made corn tortilla brought it all together.  These were some of the best corn tortillas I have had.  They are thick and fresh from the griddle.

There are many more things to come from this spot, such as family meals to debut in the near future.  For now, it seems they are open for lunch and maybe brunch only. 

Atmosphere is like you would expect from your home.  Friendly and attentive.  Beer and wine are available.  Parking is a problem in the neighborhood with meters on Mission, or in the surrounding blocks.

I'm looking forward to trying much more.  It's always nice to hear a success story like this.
author: Michael M.

description:
Incredible home made Mexican food authentic flavor from Mexico City, something hard to find this days in a hipster mission!

The owner started selling food in her house for years until now they own their own restaurant proud for the Latino entrepreneurs making a true diference on the community
author: Dr G X.

description:
Authentic flavorful Mexican dishes with very good drinks (micheladas & margaritas). 

Fast friendly service.... overall good vibe! 

Unexpected spot in San Francisco, definitely worth a visit :)
author: Mary G.

description:
This is the real deal," quipped a dear friend and dining partner. Authentic delicious Mexican food with soul. We attended last night's soft opening tasting.

Kudos and congratulations to chef/owner Isabel Caudillo on the occasion of the opening of her very first restaurant El Buen Comer in Bernal Heights. 

The restaurant will open for lunch beginning this Thursday. June 9, and will offer dinner starting on July 1. Must-EAT!

Isabel, who immigrated from Mexico City, started cooking and offering meals in her home in 2006 when Caleb first tasted her amazing dishes. Since then, San Francisco's La Cocina has guided her journey that has culminated in this wonderful beautiful brick and mortar spot. WOW food! Love every bite.
author: aL Z.

description:
This is one of those places that I was hoping to like, primarily because many of my friends raved about it.  The place did not live up to the hype, at least not for me.  The service was decent to above average, and at the time we arrived, the restaurant had not yet been over taken by disheveled millennials, so energy in the restaurant was decent as well.

I'm sure the restaurant was okay once; but, there are other restaurants that serve great if not better food for a lot less (one plate of milanese de res, and one of camarones a la diabla, a small bowl of guacamole, two beers and two sangrias = $90+, including the tip). If you wanted an extra corn tortilla, that was another $1.50, which to me seems mighty unreasonable - I know how to make tortillas, so I was not impressed that they were "hand made."  I've also not ever been warned in a Mexican restaurant that the habanero salsa might be too piquant.  It was an odd piece of advice; but, it kind of told me a lot about the clientele and who really patronizes the place.  Many places in the Mission make their own tortillas, have different kinds of salsa without salsa warnings, don't charge that much and have their families in tow - not here. The servings were stingy - not at all what I'm used to in Mexican food.  Both our plates very small servings of rice and beans and my camarones and chelada had way too much lime, which made my meal very tart.

The food was okay; but, as soon as we walked out of the restaurant, I turned to my husband and asked if he liked the place. That's all I needed to ask to know we were not going back there again because the price of food, portions and overall meal did not impress either of us.
author: Criss R.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. But it didn't meet my expectations.
This place is totally not for vegetarians.  C'mon it's SF :)  You gotta have something for the vegetarians. The calabazitas guisado was just sauteed veggies. There was no spice, nothing. The worst part is $11 for plain sauteed veggies!!!
Chicken mole was ok. But not great.
House made tortillas were really good.  Good service!
author: ST T.

description:
Mexican Food for White People

Venue: Attractive, clean and very, Very, VERY loud. You will find yourself having to yell at your dining companions to be heard. The noise level actually becomes painful.

Food: Bland, undistinguished Mexican food somewhat over priced for this fare. 

Service: Fast, professional, cold.

A sterilized Mexican food experience for non-Latinos who would not enter a more traditional Mexican restaurant. That may well be what you're looking for.
author: Thomas M.

description: Maybe it was an off night?!  Everything was extremely over salted and our albondigas and pork meat were very dry!  The pulled chicken sopes were good but not amazing!  Sopes are one of my favorites.  I ask my grandma to make them for me every year for my birthday so perhaps that's why I was underwhelmed.
author: Jackie L.

description: Ok so i was suppose to eat at the place across the street from El Buen Comer when I parked my car I saw Mexico City style food . I told my gf let's go eat here I'm from Mexico City so I wanted to try it why not . I'll start with the food  im looking at the menu and I saw the had a pambazo my mom makes so great pambazo is a delicious dish to eat but slot of people rush it or they give it to you saggy or with big pieces potato and not enough longanisa o chorizo  so i order one i was a little worry .The restaurant wasn't to busy i order a jarrito my gf order guayaba water  we had already order my food and been sitting for a while i notice other tables had chips  I had to ask the guy if that was free or had to pay I was hungry I wanted to something to grub while waiting for my food  it took quite a while for my food . Finally get my order i tried the pambazo it was a little cold the bread was cold wich i know that couldn't happen if it was serve to me right away that was sitting there  that's why it got a little cold  but it had a great taste super traditional I even texted my mom and said this is the best pambazo I've had in a restaurant hands down we also had chilaquilles almost at the end of the meal I order cafe de olla and platanitos that took me to my childhood in Mexico City  I want to rate the food *****. Stars . Now service I had to pretty much get the attention of my sever he was chilling wondering around laughing.  I had to get up or literally wave at him to get his attention I told my gf I bet you their all family that's why their chill we were almost don't with our meal my plate was sitting there for a while I was waiting for my gf to finish she ask me if I wanted  dessert she had to get up to get a menu from the front a white couple sat next to us  o over heard them saying i don't know what that is they were curious about the menu I had to help them and explain the food the server was no where to be found . As we walk out we talk to the hostess I said the food was good she said my Tia is the Cheff I looked at my Gf like see I was right she said we are all family the servers  are my cousins. Places is good but the Tia has to step up the customer service of it wasn't for the service i would give this place 5 stars .
author: Ivan M.

description:
Random Yelp find in the Mission district, and so glad we stumbled upon it! Leaving the mob scene at the park, we wanted to get far enough away for parking. Yelped this one, and made a reservation online (there were 5 of us). Realized we were going to be late, so I called (twice) and they were delightful both times. With 3 kids, I cannot tell you how thrilled we were that they didn't do the old, "sure we'll have a table," when they really don't. We walked in, they removed the "reserved" sign and seated us immediately. Hooray!
Great atmosphere, and super nice staff. Now, the food. The little guy is the non adventurous type, so he got a quesadilla, made special. The rest of us did the full family style dinner, and it did not disappoint in quality or quantity! Favorites were the delicious salsas, guacamole, and chips, and I'm now borderline obsessed with the jicama with orange and chili (WOW that was delicious!). The sopes were deliciously crisp and tender, and loaded with delicious toppings. The tacos were excellent, and the mole was perfectly rich and flavorful. The albondigas were a hit as well, and the tortillas were so fresh, HOT, and delicious I couldn't stop eating them, and I never eat the tortillas! The only word of caution- we forgot to say "no chicharones please" so we did end up with a couple of items that we couldn't eat, but that was our fault. If you don't like the chicharones, just make sure to let them know in advance, and they'll leave them out for you!
Dessert was a pile of crisp, fantastic churros and chocolate sauce, creamy flan, and coffee that had a slightly spiced (hint of cinnamon) touch. 
Definitely recommend if you're in the neighborhood, or if you just want a relaxed, fun, delicious and authentic Mexican dining experience!
author: Cindy B.

description: Best posole verde I've ever had! Felt like I was back in Mexico City with the beautiful vibes. 0 wait time for a seat on a Sunday. Highly recommended!!!!!!
author: Angel FunkyFusion G.

description:
Overdue first visit to our neighborhood restaurant.

Clean, bright room with tables not piled on each other.

Service - timely, efficient..didn't have to ask for water refills...before I knew I dropped my napkin he was there with a new one.

Food - perfection! The dark mole was thick and rich like I've had in homes outside of Oaxaca city. Tortillas homemade and perfectly tasting masa. The texture of the beans were spot on - that perfect mix of soft and slightly hard.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Very good brunch, very authentic - read about it in the NY Post as being one of the best in the country so I had HIGH expectations. And I expected more options for brunch but menu was actually lunch.  Seemed a little over priced for small Mexican venue - $3 coffee that didn't taste like coffee!
But good and I would recommend, just not awesome.
author: Lizzie R.

description:
Great food, great space, good service. Proper restaurant; not counter service or "hole in the wall."

Food:
Well made, good variety, good quality ingredients, great taste. Would love to try more.

Had a mole and a taco special. Both great.

Space:
Super clean, very inviting, fully realized.
author: Ryan B.

description: Best Mexican food place in San Francisco! The ingredients are really nice and high quality and the dishes are all really well done. The service is really lovely and the family style dishes are fun to share. Don't miss it!
author: Urban S.

description:
If you want to try REAL AUTHENTIC MEXICAN FOOD 
THIS IS THE PLACE!!! 

Service is great , the environment is awesome and it's delicious. 
As a Mexican it has been really hard to find a good and authentic Mexican restaurant but now that I found it I can recommend it..!!
author: Alinka E.

description: Good authentic Mexican food. It makes me feel like I'm in Mexico City. The service is fast and friendly. I did take away one star because it is pricey. If you come here, try the chicken mole and the tinga tostadas.
author: Karen C.

description: Excellent lunch! Had the enchiladas in tomatillo sauce. I'm not Mexican and no expert, but this does taste close to some of the great eats I enjoyed in Mexico City that it says it stays true to! Smaller portions for SF prices. I love that their enchiladas have a slight crunch to them on the bottom, not just  soggy, and the sauce is definitely fresh! No photos-- I ate it all.
author: Jen H.

description: Delicious! One of my favorite spots. The food is spot on, the Sangria is top-notch, the service is great! Worth a trip to the edge of the Mission!
author: Nissa A.

description: Amazing food! There is a great family feel and I especially love reading the story of how this restaurant came to be! Highly recommend.
author: Mandi J.

description:
This place is sooooooo good. The pork with green mole is the perfect bite- delicious texture, savory flavor, and cooked to perfection. I'd hate to see this place be over run by fickle Yelp users but I'm confident that they can handle it. 

Authentic food in a beautiful space served by friendly people at good prices. What more can you ask for?
author: Luis A.

description: The worst Mexican food I've ever tried. Tacos expensive and on top of that dry. The sopes 5 dollars each and tiny, they don't even fry them those aren't sopes. If you think this is delicious Mexico City you haven't tried legit Mexico City food. If you're looking for legit, great tasting Mexican food don't come here.
author: Jenny H.

description: Excellent, authentic Mexican food made with love and care. I was fortunate enough to work with Isabelle, the owner, when she went through La Cocina's program and I am so proud of her accomplishments. Being part Mexican myself and having lived in Mexico city, I'm extra picky about Mexican food, especially because it tends to be more Tex mex/ american, with not the most fresh ingredients. Not the case at El Buen Comer. I can't wait to go back!!!!
author: Monique P.

description:
Large and clean with a cool decor.  Looks promising.  Enchilada verde for lunch, tacos for
my guest along with a salad.  Just tap water  resulted in a tab just under $50.00.
Was it good, was it worth it, do I understand all the rave Yelp reviews, will I be back. No, no, no, and no.
author: Steve T.

description: I grew up in Mexico City and El Buen Comer reminds me of home! If you're in the mood for AUTHENTIC and delicious Mexican food, this is the place!! Always such a great experience!
author: Amanda B.

description:
First impression, not a typical Taqueria or a Mexican restaurant. Not in a bad way. 

The food is good, I wish it was slightly more authentic for my personal taste. The home made tortillas are amazing, gotta say they're the best I've had.

The thing I noticed most, restaurant is very clean and organized, staff is friendly and very helpful.
author: Z ..

description: Ordered a bunch of stuff to pick up whilst visiting in Bernal.  Arrived at the requested 20 minute mark and was greeted w. my order and a smile.  Food is gooood here- molé is correct and jicama/lime/naranja salad rocks.
author: David M.

description: Went back after 6 months. The difficulties with service are more resolved now, and the red mole was fantastic.
author: Pia C.

description:
More like 3.5

You walk in, excited, and hungry. Happy the place isn't full on a Sunday morning. You greet the host like any gentleman would for a young woman.
(Slouched over with a sideways look, chewing gum with her mouth open [gross!], and playing with her fake nails).
The host instead turns her back, turns around after joking and doesn't greet you back. She just simply looked past me into the street and asked if I had a reservation but as if Ray Charles asked me and without a smile. Not expecting her to give me southern hospitality realness but just being approachable isn't a task, it's a skill. To be acknowledged is all I'm going for. I was just happy to be there.

How do you think that would make you think? It's all up to interpretation but I was a little put off by how I was received.

I ordered the Puerco en mole Verde, posole rojo (soup of the day) and a cafe de olle to keep it rolling.

The posole was rich and not watery but a spicy taste that was a good burn and I liked it.
The mole Verde was so good. It had that spicy, cilantro, and avocado salsa aftertaste which complemented the pork so well. I enjoyed my meal.

I would go back but maybe I'll just reserve a table and maybe I might at least get a hello. 

For 3.5 stars..  they ran out of avocados before 12 which is weird. You can't be a taqueria ON Mission street and have that problem. The Host was not setting a good example on how to be the face of a restaurant.

However, the wait staff, the waittress and the busser picked up the slack and we're very attentive. I liked their work ethic and approach.
author: David C.

description: Amazing food and cute neighborhood spot! However I wish they had more vegetarian options, than just plain cheese!
author: S J.

description: Awesome mexican food.  My only complaint is that I didn't have enough space to eat more.  Will definitely come again.  I had the chicken mole enchiladas,  guacamole and chips, and a chorizo con papa sope.  Mmmmmmmmmmmm.
author: Chris M.

description: Excellent, excellent, excellent! The food was great: sopas with nopales (wonderfully spiced cactus) and carnitas and carne salada were so good. Also, the waiter was nice and attentive. The place itself is spacious and mycelium decorated. Highly recommended!
author: Barbara P.

description:
So finally, we get actual quality Mexican food in San Francisco! I've been waiting a long time for it!

This isn't your typical "San Francisco Mexican" restaurant - you aren't going to find the usual taqueria fare here. Instead, the menu focuses on guisados. The food is clearly made with love, and the people who work here are incredibly friendly.

It's a bit on the expensive side, which is my only complaint.

I highly recommend the albondigas - they're some of the best I've had.
author: Kyle D.

description: I am a frequent noe valley farmers market visitor specifically for their tamales on Saturdays. I finally was able to come into their physical location for breakfast and was not disappointed. I was able to get my pozole, which was super delicious! And my boyfriend got chilaquiles, which he also really enjoyed. Love the restaurant space itself, it's spacious and modern and makes you feel welcome. The people that work there are all so attentive and so nice. I would also recommend a reservation and f more than 2 people are aiming so you can have a table when you need one. The place fills up fast! I will most definitely be coming back
author: Rosie S.

description: I was hoping for knock my socks off Mexican food based on reviews, and granted I will say the sopes were pretty tasty, everything felt overpriced. The service was average, but the real kicker is that my friend and I both got really sick after eating there. I don't think I'll be back, at least not for a while.
author: Morgan V.

description: Came here for a change of pace from the standard taquerias.  We had a variety of the tostadas  and the meatballs (abondigas) with a side of the homemade tortillas.  The stewed pork rinds in green salsa was money.  Overall, It was definitely tasty, a little bit on the pricier side, but I aslo left stuffed.  It's a nice place to treat yourself and switch it up a bit.
author: David N.

description:
The food was tasty , but the menu/price was ridiculous. 
Small Shrimp bowl $18.00 didn't come with rice, beans or even a tortilla. If you want chips and salsa plan on paying more for that also. The flan was good. I won't be back, there are too many good restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: N G.

description: Very authentic mexican food. Tasty, homade and well prepared. Nopales salad was perfect - cactus was tender paired with light flavors of cilantro, onion and tomatoe. Chorizo con pappas was seasoned well with just enough salt and queso to leave you wanting more. Chile relleno was the best ever - lightly batteted and fluffy, melted cheese and the chile was just the right firmness to hold up in the sauce. Homeade corn tortillas and rice were so light. The rice was fluffy, seasoned and tasty - just like home. Lovely service and staff. This place is amazing.
author: phil b.

description: Es muy bueno!!! Delicioso!!! Anytime I come to SF i eat here because it is so tasty!!! Love the fresh, delicious food, fantastico friendly service, and the best homemade tortillas ever!!!!
author: judi o.

description: Wow, this place is one of the best sit-down Mexican restaurants I've been to. Their sopes were awesome and not dense like you normally find, their handmade tortillas and chips were fresh. Also really liked the homey clay plates and bowls and the casual atmosphere. Our server was also genuinely friendly and attentive. You do need to pay extra for rice, beans, and tortillas, so if that upsets you this isn't for you. But I found everything to be really worth it. Definitely returning with some friends!
author: Brian R.

description:
Mediocre at best. The food was extremely underwhelming considering the reviews that have been left here. Overall I'll say that the service was truly the reason why I am giving 3 stars. 

Small portions, lack of flavor, and overly chewy tortillas.
author: Gavin L.

description:
I usually have to go to Los Angeles when I need to eat Mexican, and I've been complaining for 2 decades that there are no decent Mexican eateries in SF, no more.

It's real Mexican, none of that burritos SF Mex.It's fantastic, my new favorite restaurant. 

Fresh spice salsas, and they make their own chips. I had the chicken tacos, they were generous, and delicious. 

The sangria was honest. The space is light and comfortable, and they treated me like family.

And it's in my neighborhood!
author: Renee R.

description: I love El Buen Comer! The name says it all -- damned good food. Plus super friendly service.
author: Robert W.

description: Authentic Mexican cuisine that was fantastic! The prawns were fiery but complex. The cactus tacos unbelievable.
author: Tzeporah B.

description: This place is really good, and I could tell it was as soon as I walked in and smelled roasting chiles. I had the halibut ceviche which was fresh and bright and came with a basket of homemade chips. I also tried a side of the refried black beans which were creamy and delicious. The carnitas taco was really good too; simple and clean, with a fresh homemade tortilla, some nice tomatillo salsa, white onion and cilantro. I saw many other things on the menu that I would have liked to try. I'll be going back before long.
author: timothy b.

description: I give it a 4. It was a nice place to sit down to eat and the service was alright. The food was pretty decent but you can tell they are just experimenting with the menu selection. A bigger menu would be nice, but the plates are good.
author: J M.

description:
Amazing. Superb. As I write this review the morning after I am trying to remember if I have ever had better Mexican food anywhere. Even counting places like Nopalito or the amazing Hierbabuena near Todos Santos, Mexico, I can't think of anything quite as good as this.
A buddy and I shared (which is the best way to enjoy this place) a few dishes, including the green mole with pork, Albondigas (meatballs), black beans and rice and of course the show stopping home made tortillas. 
We started with the chorizo laden tostada, which is a small tostada type appetizer. The accompanying tomatillo salsa was excellent, but I didn't think this dish was mind blowing. Great but not over the top. It was the first bite of the green mole with pork scooped into one of the heavenly tortillas though that nearly had me in tears. That dish is hard to put into words. It tastes like the most authentic, home style, velvety, rich but not too rich spiced perfectly, creamy, delectable insanely awesome dish you have ever tasted. I just sat there in disbelief. Seriously, it was that good to me.
We ordered a few margs which were excellent. The accompanying rice and beans were of perfect texture, taste and quality.
This place immediately shot up to the top of my All Time All Star list and is currently hovering around the top spot for favorite restaurants in the City. 
It was already an hour wait for a table so maybe you shouldn't take my word for it and go somewhere else, but I thought it best and the right thing to do to give a review with mad props for the owners of this place, who have brought to SF some of the most incredible food the City has seen. And that's saying a lot. Bravo!!
author: Matt H.

description:
Just tried this restaurant for the first time. My husband said it was the best carne asada he has ever had! This is a cute family owned neighborhood place with a friendly atmosphere.
The tortillas are also delicious.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Listen, this place is delicious, authentic, something you would eat at a Mexican families house. However, most Mexicans would find the prices and portion size absolutely ridiculous, I'm speaking to you also Loló. I would give the place 5 stars but in good conscious I can't, my mother makes those exact dishes at home for not a lot of money so I suspect you are turning a pretty good profit El Buen Comer. Quite often I drive by your establishment and most of the time it only looks only semi-full. Please reconsider your portion size if you can't lower the prices. You've got good quality food but perhaps a smaller space with less overhead would be more fitting.  p.s. Both the chicken tinga sopes, papas con chorizo sopes (you can never go wrong with chorizo) are legit and their strong Margarita is delicious (great value for $8) I didn't try the platos fuertes or guizados due to how overpriced they were and tortillas do not come included. $1.50 for two tortillas. WTH but I digress.. If you've got the extra money or no sense of what things should cost, give it a try.
author: A V.

description: Our favorite Sat. brunch Mexican food proprietor in Noe Valley opened a full restaurant to feature their amazing cuisine in the Mission!  The Camarones el diablo, shrimp with white wine and chile arbol sauce stays on your tongue and mind.  The tacos are served on artisanal quality organic tortilla with chorizos, carnitas, pollo+++ & nopal filling choices that taste like home cooked meals.  From homemade salsas, varied entrees to margaritas, our family found the long lost Mexican restaurant we loved in SoCal & Mexico City.  Gracias familia El buen comer!
author: Susan C.

description:
This restaurant is DELICIOUS. I've come here for lunch about once a week since it opened. Fresh, delicious, different food. The sopes are delicious, so are the homemade tortillas, and the service is fantastic.

Run, don't walk to this place!!!
author: Karen H.

description: Delicious food that feels homecooked in a warm, lovely atmosphere. The service was friendly and the menu begs many more visits. It is, as others have mentioned, not the least expensive option around, but I imagine rent prices these days require that. I maybe got too relaxed by the warm food and environment, and ended up leaving my bag behind! 1,000 thanks to the guest who ran out in the rain to tell me! Extra star for such kind clientele ;) Really enjoyed our first lunch at this neighborhood restaurant and will be back!
author: Tria C.

description: Reminds me of my (Mexican) family every time.  Authentic, simple, wonderful.  Among my favorite Mexican restaurants in the Bay.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Incredible restaurant. A must for anyone who wants the best of Mexican food in SF... Scratch hat in the Bay Area! Service is attentive, the setting is impeccable, and the food is second to none. Try the chorizo and chicken taco appetizers and DO NOT miss the poached pear desert.

The owners are friendly and deserve every star they've received so far for their new restaurant.
author: Olivier B.

description: I had a great time with family today the Meals were amazing the service was really good the staff was accommodating and the online Feature work great
author: Tina O.

description: Super tasty and genuine treats from Mexico. We had the chef's choice-abundant and an excellent variety. We were seated immediately at our reserved table. The staff was very attentive and pleasant. Looking forward to returning.
author: Stephen R.

description:
